Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Theory, Techniques and Simulations of RF Impedance Probes for Plasma Characterization
Award.AbstractNarration: This research will be the first effort to use Radio Frequency Impedance Probes to measure and characterize a wide range of ambient plasma environments. The potential to use RF impedance probe techniques for measuring plasma parameters, such as temperatures and collision frequencies, has not yet been demonstrated due to lack of a sufficiently rigorous scientific model of the probe plasma interaction. Nonlinear properties of the probe plasma interaction are poorly understood and these properties have not been exploited. The first component of this research is to develop novel RF Impedance Probe techniques to obtain the probe-plasma frequency response in space plasmas. Graduate and undergraduate students will use the Universal Software Radio (USRP) hardware architecture together with open source software as a platform for the instrument related research. The second component of the project is the development of a theoretical and computational tool called RFPIC-PROBE that accurately simulates the interaction of the RF Impedance Probe with the surrounding plasma environment in order to analyze the frequency response data. The design of electronic circuits for space based measurements of plasma properties requires creative techniques to compensate for the quickly changing ambient plasma environment and to mitigate the effects of plasma interaction with a spacecraft. The research also develops mathematical and computational techniques to account for the gradual transition from collisional to fully collisionless interactions in ionospheric plasmas. The applications of this research range from space plasma diagnostics to laboratory plasma measurements and control of industrial plasma processes. The RF Impedance probe will provide a powerful means to measuring the properties of these plasmas. The RFPIC-PROBE software will be made available in the public domain under General Public License for use by researchers in different areas of plasma diagnostics. Graduate and undergraduate students will use readily available open source game engines to develop a real time space exploration strategy game where players choose instruments for missions to explore and probe the environments of different planets. As part of outreach, a workshop session will be introduced through the Alabama Science in Motion program to allow high school students and teachers to try out computer experiments to measure the properties of a hypothetical plasma medium. All results and data from this research project will be hosted on the world wide web, and made freely available for public or industrial use and collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to research and develop new techniques for probing plasmas in the earth's ionosphere using a specialized instrument called a Plasma Impedance Probe. In order to successfully understand and analyze the measurements and interaction of this probe with the plasma environment, the project also included the development of a full Maxwell 3D Particle In Cell Code.


Intellectual Merit

The first intellectual outcome of this project was the development of a new, time domain method for plasma impedance probes. This new time domain impedance probe (TDIP) prototype was designed, developed and integrated into a NASA Undergraduate Student Instrument Program (USIP) sounding rocket that was launched out of Wallops Flight Facility on March 1 2016. The traditional method used to extract the local plasma density from a frequency sweep with an impedance probe performs on the order of 1 sweep every 10 milliseconds. Although this method is accurate and robust, it is more suited to laboratory plasmas, unlike in space plasmas where typically a cubesat traveling at 7 km per second covers 70 meters of plasma in 10 milliseconds. A time domain approach is shown to be significantly faster. A single measurement is performed in 100 microseconds, which improves the instantaneous resolution to 0.7 meter per measurement for satellites in LEO. The data obtained from this probe was used to refine the technique, and resulted in two publications. A new version of this probe is now being built as payload on a 2U CubeSat funded by NASA under the Undergraduate Student Instrument Program (USIP) to be launched out of the ISS in early 2022. The Time Domain Impedance Probe (TDIP) on this CubeSat will perform measurements of plasma density in the upper ionosphere faster than any previous instrument. This will enable researchers to understand the sources of small scale irregularities that occur in the ionosphere, and their mechanisms.

The second intellectual outcome of this project is the development of a full electromagnetic 3D Particle In Cell code (PIC) that can be used to analyze the linear and nonlinear interactions of electron plasmas with radio frequency signals. This code is currently being validated for simple cases of electron waves and resonances in a plasma, and against sounding rocket data at higher altitudes. The code is implemented in C++, while the supporting algorithms were validated using MATLAB. The code will be fully tested when we use it to analyze the CubeSat impedance probe data obtained at 410 km altitudes.

Broader Impacts

There were several broader impacts as a result of this project. During the development of the new instrument, several graduate students were involved. These graduate students analyzed sounding rocket data and prepared the specifications for the new instrument. The graduate students also assisted in the development of the plasma PIC software.

More than 50 students of different background, electrical engineering, computer engineering, computer science, mechanical engineering, and Physics, have been actively involved with all aspects of the new instrument and it's integration, first on a sounding rocket, then, on the 2U CubeSat. These students were significantly impacted in their choice of career objectives as a result of their involvement. Several of them chose to pursue a space science and engineering related career, in particular.

As a result of the work done surrounding the development of the plasma instrument and it's potential application to satellites, a female PhD student in Systems Engineering supervised by the PI is now actively developing a commercializable Space Weather Hardware Module that can be integrated into satellites to provide real time space weather situational awareness to the spacecraft main computer. The plan is to pursue an SBIR towards commercializing the module. This is a broader impact that could benefit spacecraft manufacturers in the future.
